name: Nirvrithi
description:
Nirvrithi is a state of inexplicable ecstasy. 
Through the medium of Bharatanatyam, Shijith N Parvathy takes you on a journey in pursuit of this eternal bliss, the ultimate experience. In Bharatanatyam, the Margam is a path that unravels a seeking. Through this path the dancer attains Nirvrithi. 
The concept of Satchitananda described in the central piece of the performance is what Shijith N Parvathy through their conceptual choreographic Margam takes you to experience. Nirvrithi is woven from manifested inner thoughts to stimulate the body, mind and soul. 
For Shijith N Parvathy, Bharatanatyam is a spiritual recourse and Nirvrithi is their experience. 
This is the fourth edition of the ‘All For Dance’ series presented by Kalavaahini in association with BIC curated by Malavika Sarukkai. The ‘All For Dance’ series is presented every quarter at BIC to spotlight some of the best of classical dance from across India. The series is supported by Tanishq and Taneira. The event is managed by Shreya Nagarajan Singh Arts Department Consultancy. 
In collaboration with:
 
Supported by:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Harmonica Magic
description:
Many years ago, in Detroit during a chance meeting with Jerry Murad of the Harmonicats, a commitment was made. Sulaiman Jamal met Jerry Murad at a harmonica convention, and he asked Sulaiman to continue playing the chromatic harmonica. He highlighted the versatility and beauty of the small instrument. That was Sulaiman’s motivation and inspiration to continue playing the unique instrument which he had actually put in cold storage. 
While Jerry had passed away many years ago, Sulaiman was reminded by a mutual friend that he had not fulfilled Jerry’s request – This concert is to do just that. 
The theme of the concert is to cover some of the greatest Broadway and cinema themes, mainly from yesteryear which have warmed our hearts. 
The evening will include favourites from Phantom of the Opera, The Wizard of Oz, Jesus Christ Superstar, Fiddler on the Roof and more. Not to forget the classics from The Beatles, Leonard Cohen, Simon and Garfunkel, and Big Band and Blues numbers. 
With a group of extremely talented and accomplished musicians, the evening can’t be anything but memorable. The magic of the Harmonica and an incredible music ensemble awaits you. 
Presented by: 
 
Supported by:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Carving a Legacy
description:
The 12th-13th century Hoysala temples of Belur, Halebidu, and Somanathapura were recently recognised as UNESCO World Heritage. They are known for their stunning architecture and sculpture. This talk will explore some of their unique aspects, the rigorous process of UNESCO nomination for World Heritage status, and the outstanding values of these stunning temples that ultimately secured their coveted World Heritage status. 
Presented by the International Music and Arts Society

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Jod | In Resonance
description:
Join us for an evening of traditional Hindustani music, featuring a duet performance showcasing the rich interplay between voice and flute. 
Experience a jugalbandi with vocalist Anirudh Aithal and flautist Shadaj Godkhindi, combining melodies with intricate rhythms. Vignesh Bhagavat on harmonium will provide supportive textures, while Roopak Kallurkar on tabla will bring dynamic rhythmic patterns. 
In collaboration with:
 
Supported by:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Rhythms of the Desert
description:
Langa and Manganiyar musicians of Rajasthan are a hereditary community of professional musicians from the villages of Barmer, Balotra, Jodhpur, Phalodi and Jaisalmer in the desert areas of western Rajasthan. They have a vast repertoire of folk music integral to their way of life and social systems. Their music, which has been preserved and passed down through generations, acts as a medium of information and storytelling, much like the postcards in your exhibition. 
The Manganiars’ music has survived for decades thanks to the traditional Jajmani (patronage) system, which supports their art form and livelihood. Their music has continued to survive for decades mainly because of the Jajmani (patronage) system, which is fundamental to their art form as well as the source of traditional livelihood. These traditional patrons have been supporting the economy of the communities of Langa and Manganiyar musicians for generations. 
An eight-member team led by Sardar Khan Langa & Sawai Khan Manganiyar will present traditional folk music of Rajasthan along with Kalbeliya song & dance. Sardar Khan is a senior Langa guru, a very knowledgeable person of Barnawa Jageer, and has traveled worldwide to present traditional folk music. Sawai is a young Khartal player of Barna Jaisalmer who has collaborated with various world music maestros. The other members of the team consist of Deu Khan in vocals, Sikander Khan in Sindhi Sarangi & Algoza, and Goram Khan in Dholak. This music group will be accompanied by a three-member Kalbelia team including two dancers and one musician. 
In collaboration with:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Musical Ecologies
description:
What is nature? Though it is a term used so ubiquitously, its meaning has been debated and questioned, changing with each era. While trees, animals and the planets are considered natural elements, it is the human relationship to nature that concerns us the most. Aren’t humans too part of nature, rather than external to it? What is the relationship between humans and nature? Is it merely utilitarian, or is there hope that can it be something more? 
Musical Ecologies is an exploration of how music and art can answer such questions for us, by showing us how to experience nature as a world of emotion. Hindustani music has a long tradition of celebrating natural beauty and seasons. These compositions capture the subjective human response to nature, locating humans very much inside the natural ecosystem as co-habitants. Perhaps by relating to nature on its own terms rather than from a position of control or exploitation, we can contemplate a symbiotic model of living for the future. 
Hindustani vocalist Priya Purushothaman presents bandishes and raags that celebrate the environment and its rich ecosystems, interspersed with commentary addressing these philosophical questions, suggesting a way of bringing together environmental consciousness and music. 
The session will also include readings and a discussion with Musician, Playwright and Social Justice Worker Rumi Harish. 
  
In collaboration with: 
  
Supported by:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Till Death Us Do Part
description:
The marital and the martial are sometimes interchangeable in the long-term landscape. As infidelity and indifference run through many relationships, and the future looks polyamorous, are marriages going out of fashion? 
Authors Selma Carvalho, Shinie Antony and author/relationship counsellor Vijay Nagaswami are all set to discuss the unholy state of matrimony with journalist/author Prajwal Hegde. 
The discussion will be followed by a Q&A session with the audience.

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Neighbourhood Narratives
description:
Experience Bangalore through the eyes of those who have explored its streets with curiosity and passion. 
In this session, listen to a variety of curated experiences uncovering the lesser-known facets of Bangalore that often go unnoticed. From the bustling markets to tranquil bookstores, from historical landmarks to contemporary cafes, these narratives offer a blend of personal reflection and historical research. 
The topics presented will be the Karaga Connection, Literary Trails and Cafe Crawls.  
Whether you’re a lifelong Bangalorean or new to the city, you’ll leave with a deeper understanding and appreciation of Bangalore’s unique character and charm. 
In collaboration with:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Kathas in Kathak
description:
Kathak, one of India’s most iconic classical dance forms, has continuously evolved over centuries, shaped by the dynamic interplay of poetry, politics, and cultural shifts. Imperative to its evolution are the poetic narratives and political landscapes that have informed and transformed both its content and form. 
In this performance, Madhu Nataraj and the Natya STEM Dance Kampni present a space-temporal retelling of Kathak’s rich history. Through an array of rare, vintage, and contemporary choreographies, the dancers weave together the past and the present, allowing historical veracity to coexist with artistic resilience. 
This unique performance delves into Kathak’s diverse journey across regions and eras, offering an insightful exploration of how artistic expression has both shaped and been shaped by the socio-political contexts of its time. From the courts of ancient kingdoms to the modern stage, the show showcases Kathak’s timeless beauty and enduring adaptability, all while celebrating the dance’s poetic spirit. 
In collaboration with:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Inside India’s Red Corridor
description:
The Red Corridor remains one of the most complex and challenging areas in India, marred by Naxal-State conflict, that has been shaping the lives of its residents for over half a century. In the years of reporting from the conflict zone of Bastar, journalist Ashutosh Bhardwaj pieced together The Death Script: Dreams and Delusions in Naxal Country. 
In this session, Ashutosh will shed light on his experience in the conflict zone – reporting on the Maoist, the state atrocities, the plight of the Adivasis caught in the civil war and what it means to live through and write about these experiences as a journalist and a bilingual writer. He will talk about deviating from the traditional form of journalistic writing into more creative ones and the crossroads where these forms converge and diverge. The talk will also offer insights into the status of the Hindi media, its role in shaping the Hindi belt polity, and the urgent need to focus on and invest in this media section. 
Ashutosh Bhardwaj will be in conversation with Kannada author Vasudhendra followed by a Q&A session with the audience.

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Object Stories
description: You’ve read books. You’ve read comics. You’ve read magazines. But have you ever read an object? From ancient times, inventive humans have created objects to enrich their world. Join award-winning children’s author Devika Cariapa as she introduces her latest book, A Children’s History of India in 100 Objects and learn to read clues from some of these old material remains. Turn into ‘object detectives’ as tiny coins and crumbling pottery reveal secrets of the long-ago people who made them. Then, write your own exciting object stories. Discover a whole new way of understanding the past!

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Her Voice
description:
Her Voice by SaMaRaSa is an exploration of compositions that are created by women, or about women, set in the context of a Carnatic concert, but with a novel approach. The musicians explore the nuances of the raga, lyric and soul of the composition, while sharing what each piece means to them personally as women and artistes. Interspersed with spoken word and poetry, this concert will be an intimate yet exciting journey into the world of raga and rhythm. They will share inspirational stories of fearless artistes who conquered barriers within and without to leave a lasting legacy. 
Presenting the concert are three accomplished musicians – Manasi Prasad (vocals), Aditi Krishnaprakash (violin) and Deepika Sreenivasan (mridangam) who have travelled the world sharing their music. In addition, their academic and corporate credentials have enabled them to develop a world view that is unique, contemporary and relevant. 
‘SaMaRaSa’ – Sisters in Harmony, is a collective of women musicians who believe that music not only entertains and elevates, but can also create change. Through performances and ideas that celebrate women, SaMaRaSa aims to bring fresh ideas to the way Carnatic music is presented and performed. 
Supported by:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: सिल्वटें | Silvatein
description:
90 minutes | Hindi | Suitable for 16 years+

On a day unknown, at a place not known, two people run into one another. They soon start talking to each other, but they seem to be conversing at cross purposes. They seem to be long-lost lovers but, at the same time, seem to be perfect strangers. They seem to have had a life together but, at the same time, seem to have had lives apart. They seem to occupy differing realities but simultaneously seem to be in someone’s dream. Who are they? Where are they? Are they actually strangers? Or do they indeed know each other? Is this even real?
Or is it only someone’s imagination? 
Director’s Note:  
The experience of writing this play, and now producing and directing it for the stage, have been cathartic and instrumental in helping me emerge from a difficult year. I am now eager to see how audiences respond to this attempt by our merry band of artists to tell a story from all our lives. I am absolutely swept with the power of community as I see how the cast and crew has worked relentlessly to bring Silvatein on stage, amidst laughter, excitement and pure joy of working together. It is a prime example of the passion, honesty and commitment that brings forward a story about two individuals caught in a web of lies or deceit or it something completely imaginative. This play is intensely special to me, not only because I have written and directed it but also because the themes and characters are inspired from real life and real incidents that will provoke the audience to reflect on their own experiences. Silvatein is a piece of writing that managed to paint a picture of a world of intimate details that devastates Rupali and Arijit and somehow manages to be bite sized. The characters are delightfully complex and multifaceted and the story feels comfortingly familiar. 
Credit List: 
Set Design: Puneet Gupta and Prachi Kalra
Light Design: Srinivas Beesetty,
Poster Design: Sweta Garg
Production Manager: Archana Kariappa and Sandeep Jain
Written and Directed by: Shatarupa Bhattacharyya
Cast: Ujani Ghosh and Sagnik Sinha 
Supported by

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Tango Ports
description:
Puertos de Tango (Tango Ports) aims to revisit lesser-known themes of great Uruguayan authors, thus keeping wonderful compositions alive. The project includes a special tribute to Astor Piazzolla and the great Uruguayan poet Horacio Ferrer, evoking much of their creative duo and reinterpreting part of their repertoire inspired by the artists’ homeland, Uruguay. In this kind of cosmopolitan tango without temporal and spatial boundaries, some versions in Italian and French are included, justified in the words of Ramón Pelinski (Argentine ethnomusicologist and composer) who describes tango as a “global metaphor”: a tango with infinite possibilities, capable of imagining and travelling to other worlds, without fear that “its entire life is yesterday, holding it in its past.” 
Natalia Bolani seeks her own interpretation from her perspective as an actor, resignifying and valuing the chosen texts through contemporary sounds, mainly appealing to the sound of the piano and the bandoneón, instruments with strong organic and referential connotations in Rio de la Plata culture. 
The project intends to attract new audiences to this genre, as well as to offer a repertoire not usually enjoyed by those more familiar with the music. Its raison d’être is, ultimately, the encounter with the emotions, a meeting where interpretive and sonorous power intermingle in the same waters, in a kind of cathartic ritual through artistic creation. 
Presented by the Embassy of Uruguay and MLC Estates LLP 
  
Supported by:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: The Story of Kalbelia
description:
Kalbelia, a vibrant and mesmerizing traditional dance form from Rajasthan, India, is inscribed on UNESCO’s 2003 Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity. This workshop offers participants a unique opportunity to immerse themselves in the rich cultural heritage of the Kalbelia community, which is closely linked to the Navnaths and believed to have gypsy origins. The name “Kalbelia” itself reflects the community’s historical connection to snake charming, with “kal” meaning snake and “belia” meaning friendship. 
Participants will explore the striking features of Kalbelia dance, known for its swirling movements and colorful costumes, which have made it one of the most captivating dance forms in India. The session will be led by renowned Kalbelia dancers, Kavita Kalbelia and Kanchan Kalbelia, from Chopasani, Jodhpur—a village famous for its Kalbelia performers. They will be accompanied by Govardhan Nath on the dafli and other musicians on the dholak and pungi. 
The session begins with an introduction to Kalbelia’s rich heritage, followed by a film screening that showcases the traditions and lifestyle of the Kalbelia community. After the film screening, the artists will present a short live performance, showcasing the energetic and captivating Kalbelia dance. This performance will highlight the intricate movements and rhythmic patterns that are the hallmark of Kalbelia. The session culminates in an interactive session where participants can learn Kalbelia dance steps and songs directly from the artists, providing a truly hands-on and memorable experience. 
In collaboration with:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: Ardha | The Incomplete Dream
description:
Ardha – The Incomplete Dream is a solo work born out of a collection of essays contained in the book, Finding Radha by Namita Gokhale and Malashri Lal. Weaving together Bharatanatyam and spoken word, Ardha looks at Radha as the ‘adhara’ in whom the essence of Krishna is held. Beyond her oft-recognized status as Krishna’s lover and his chosen gopi, Radha is ‘Hladini Shakti’ – the potency that is half of Krishna, their spirits engaged in perpetual ‘Lila Hava’- the exchange of ornaments, attire, and souls. 
Could Radha be an illusion that, through her dhara (flow) of joy and pain in union and separation, symbolizes the yearning for something beyond, a yearning that exists in every human? What happened to Radha after Krishna left Mathura? Why is Krishna celebrated while Radha, is a mere shadow in her aradhana to him? 
Credits:  
– Concept, Choreography, Dance, Spoken word: Vidhya Subramanian 
– Music Composition: Shreya Devnath 
– Sound track produced at Resound India and mixed and mastered by Sai Shravanam 
– Musicians: Keerthana Vaidyanathan, Shreya Devnath, Sivaprasad, Sruti Sagar, Sai Shravanam, Manonmani, Vidhya Subramanian 
Supported by:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India

name: SpaceAge Solutions
description:
India, being one of the developing countries in the world, does face many challenges when it comes to taking up specific developmental projects for the benefit of the people. Natural resources management and societal applications are the biggest areas for India where the Government spends lots of funds for the benefit of its people. 
Government spendings of public money in many important areas, such as, building rural and urban infrastructure, programs on land & water conservation, agriculture, water, forests, energy and many others to ensure sustainable development of all basic needs of the people, are efforts towards achieving our sustainable developmental goals. This calls for meticulous planning and well-orchestrated implementation and monitoring. 
Space technology provides many interesting solutions in terms of Earth observation, communication and GNSS based solutions. The presentation brings out specific areas where such solutions are being provided to the Government using space technology so that the goals of development and governance are met amicably. 
The talk by Prof. Diwakar will be followed by a discussion with Ecologist, Harini Nagendra. A Q&A session with the audience will follow. 
This session is part of the Let’s Talk Climate Change Talk series. 
Presented by:

location.name: Bangalore International Centre, 7, 4th Main Road, Domlur II Stage, Bangalore, Karnataka, 560071, India
